ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I greatly improved my writing skills and learned to analyze topics related to race, identity, and ecology in a new light.
I learned how to format a humanities paper properly and how to analyze sources for research.
I developed skills that helped me make connections between different course readings and draw other connections to the world today.
Learned to dissect text and put my own thoughts and inquiries into my writing.
I learned how to get through dense academic texts, as well as all things social ecologies. Lessons on plantation societies and relationally especially stuck with me.
I learned how to analyze literary texts and write better essays.
I was able to gain knowledge of the interactions between black/indigenous peoples and white colonizers. Specifically how their views differed from each other about land and ecology.

During this course I learned so much about not only colonialism the true meaning of communism and how it affects us to this day but also how to write about that how to how to articulate my own thoughts around that to someone else. This course taught me to be able to articulate my thoughts and my reasoning about topics which I previously didnt really have the tools to write about effectively. It was also very effective for me learning how to write on a time schedule and put that into practice.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: extremely tight knit seminar community. Rasheed is very responsive and cares about the writing and ideas of each student. Also, expect lots of flexibility with assignments, both with regards to deadlines but also to presentation of ideas!

Weaknesses: none!

I loved analyzing modern movies like Wakanda Forever and attributing it to the historical information we learned about Black and Indigenous history in our class discussions. I felt each paper we complete was different and based upon uniquely different topics than the previous.

I think this course was amazing! I would not change it at all. In the future, I hope students can continue to watch Black Panther: Wakanda Forever outside of class, as I think it was a nice bonding opportunity. I am closer with some of the students after watching the movie!
Class is very structured and spark great conversations within classroom. Could not find any weaknesses
I think the course could have been more on track with the readings.
The course had no weaknesses in my opinion.
I feel that the information in this course was presented well, and I feel that the material we went over was insightful and interesting.

I feel like the biggest strength of this course is definitely the instructor, Rasheed was an amazing instructor. All of our readings were so informative and interesting, and really push me to think about the topics were discussing differently.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. Whether you are an English major or someone looking for a writing credit, ENGL 114 (especially BIE with Rasheed Tazudeen) is a fantastic must-take at Yale.

Yes, I felt my class completed very interesting and inclusive conversations about Black and Indigenous struggles today. It was inspiring to be surrounded by like-minded students who held a passion for creating change.

I would absolutely recommend this course to other students, and I already have. It is my favorite class, and I made a lot of friends. I also think the material was really engaging, and I enjoyed reading articles about Indigenous futurism and Afro-futurism before class. My favorite reading was Welcome to Your Authentic Indian Experience.
Definitely. Professor is amazing, if you are interested in the topic of the environment in relation to Black and indigenous people I would strongly recommend taking the class
Yes, I would. It really introduces new perspectives and fields of knowledge that can be applied beyond studies of ecologies.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It was very eye opening and intellectually stimulating.
I would recommend this class to another student, the class itself is an interesting subject that was taught well and the workload is very reasonable for a writing class.
Yes, it was a really fascinating class.
